text: Titles begin to play over a black screen. Suddenly the screen is filled with color! An intense, glowing orange. Electronic. Flickering. A TV screen. The sound of clicking, clattering computer keyboards. A black dot appears in the field of orange, then another and another. These build into the shape of a triangle. TITLES CONTINUE. CAMERA SLOWLY DOLLIES BACK. Another black triangle appears: ‘beside the first. ‘Ey es. The face of a_jack-o-lantern is being electronically "carve into the field of orange. The triangular nose, the jagged smile... The pumpkin shape reverses and rearranges itself on the monitor screen, distorting, enlarging, shrinking, strobing, filling the screen. TITLES OUT.
©) 3. INT./EXT. LONELY GAS STATION - NIGHT 3 OPEN on another TV screen. This one is filled with dramatic shots of Stonehenge.

(V.O. filtered; with British accent) ..-leaving British authorities still baffled and. without any substantial clues nine months after the theft... the Bluestone was one of nineteen, believed to represent the nineteen- year cycle of the moon. It weighs more than five tons, making its disappearance a mystery indeed... PULL BACK to reveal a clean little gas station. The ATTENDANT, JONES, a black man in his forties, sits comfortably at his desk, feet propped up, his nose buried in a boxing magazine. Outside, the rain comes down in sheets.

(continued; V.O.) ) ...but the festival goers seemed none the worse for it, as happy celebrants gathered to welcome in the Autumn season... (a smattering of an Irish jig) Derrick Smith...at Stonehenge.
(vV.0O. filtered; very American) Aaaaaaaand when we come back, Steve will bring us. the weather and Trina sy “will. .bi ne .to-tell. you what, you" “can do ‘about .junk mail. Stay with ‘US...
Then, the bright, happy sound of a commercial. Jones glances at the set.
A logo spirals out of the video depths and fills the screen:
Jolly voices begin to sing:
Colorful masks and smiling children spiral onto the screen and dance merrily about: A WITCH, a PUMPKIN and a SKULL.

Jones turns back to his magazine. A SHAMROCK VOICE yammers about “horrificly beautiful masks at low, low prices..." In the pouring rain outside, something moves. A FIGURE separates itself from the background and heads toward the station.

The man's foot splashes hugely into frame! He staggers doggedly past the gas pumps, gasping for breath. WE FOLLOW. Something dangles from his hand; he drops it. It is a Halloween mask. An orange. pumpkin. The man staggers forward and falls against the station door.
The attendant turns, startled. * to the tune of "London Bridge Is Falling Down"  0 10

The man outside (whose name is GRIMBRIDGE) has his face pressed tight against the glass; it is a study in terror and exhaustion. His gray hair is matted. His eyes are wild. Jones opens the door and Grimbridge collapses inward. Jones helps him to the floor.
Jesus Christ, man! What happened? Grimbridge stares up at the attendant helplessly. He is emaciated. A week's growth of beard, a cut on his cheek. He slumps into unconsciousness.
(continuing) Oh man, don't die here...

The station tow-truck roars to life and backs out into the rain. Grimbridge is slumped against the passenger window. Gears grind, wheels spin and the truck hurtles into the night. PAN WITH IT, finally revealing a_tall thin figure, watching from the shadows.

The television plays. commercials..to an empty. room. Upper middle class; suburban. The front door bursts open. JOHN CHALLIS steps in gingerly, rain and lightning behind him. Square-jawed, late thirties; his hair and his clothes are all wrong for the suburbs.
(coming in) Anybody home? (CONTINUED)
il
A commotion from the other end of the house. TWO CHILDREN run into the room carrying forks, napkins, sandwiches, etc. BELLA (9) and WILLIE (10), straight from the dinner table.
(in a jumble) Daddy's here! Daddy's here! Yay, Daddy! Whadja bring us? The children both hit Challis at the same time, nearly knocking him over.

(off-screen) Children, we leave our food at the table-- Linda comes in. Pretty, well-coiffed. The perfect suburban wife. Except that she and Challis aren't married any more. She looks weary. Challis takes two paper bags from his coat.
Whadja bring us? Lemme see! Lemme see!
(to Linda; through the din) Hi. Sorry. Bad timing.

(phony pleasant) I'm used to it. Remember? . .jxCHALLIS » (to 'the'children) All right, all right! Here! He hands each child a paper bag. ON BELLA AND WILLIE il In unison, they pull Halloween masks from the bags. These aren't the kind on TV. These are smaller, and painted with dull colors. In unison, the children look disappointed.
What's wrong? Don't you like them?
Mommy already got us masks...

Silver Shamrock! Look! Challis' face falls. The children drop their gifts and scamper behind the sofa, emerging seconds later wearing two beautiful Silver Shamrock masks! Willie wears a SKULL, his sister a WITCH HEAD. They prance around the room singing the Silver Shamrock song. Linda comes over to Challis. The children settle in front of the TV.
(softening) Nice try. Challis shrugs, picks up the masks. If it hurts, he doesn't show it much. The phone RINGS. Both children lunge for it.
I'll get it! I'll get it!
(getting there first Hello? Yes. Just a moment. (at the kids) Turn that down! She holds the phone out to Challis.

They return to their perches in front of the TV, still wearing their masks. Bella turns down the volume just as the Silver Shamrock commercial comes on! Delighted, both children bob and dance to the music.
(into phone) Yeah?---when? What's his condition? wc-all right. I'll come on in. (hanging up) I've got to go.
That's a familiar line.
"Bye kids-- But the children are absorbed in their TV-dance. Challis heads for the door. Linda hurries to him. DOLLY IN CLOSE.
(lowering her voice) John, now listen to me. Saturday morning, 10:30. You're picking them up. Right? No excuses this time?
on (irritably) a, Linda...
It's been four weeks, nonstop. They're your kids too, dammit. I'm going out of my mind, John, I need some personal space!! You promised me-—-
All right. Saturday. And he is gone. Linda stares out into the rain.
(softly) Bastard. And in the background, the Silver Shamrock jingle tinkles along... CuT TO:
Challis' car slides through the wet night, rounds a curve and slices through the main street of this small California town.

Challis drives through the night. The rain lets up; he turns off the wipers. He tries the radio, twisting the dial: Jazz, rock, news, the commercial..."eight more days to Halloween, Halloween, Halloween--" Disgusted, Challis snaps the radio off.

See the hospital from some distance away: A couple of stories, modern, stark. A few cars scattered in the gaping parking lot. Challis' car pulls into a special area near the building. He gets out and heads inside. As we PAN with him, we catch a reflection in a nearby car. The tall thin man is watching.
Challis comes in. He is met by the HEAD NURSE, (AGNES), a stout woman of middle age. I. should--

His condition is stable, but Doctor Castle left early, and I just thought : CHALLIS” Sure. S'fine.’ Where is he? The nurse points ahead. They go up the hallway. WE FOLLOW. -TWO POLICEMEN are standing near a gurney on which Grimbridge is lying. Jones, the station attendant, comes over.
Lissen. He just walked up out of the rain. I swear to God that's all there was to it...I brought him here... (CONTINUED)
One of the policemen hands Challis a form to sign. Challis does so, and the policemen leave. Jones seems relieved. Challis checks Grimbridge over. He appears to be asleep.
Got a room for him?
Thirteen. Challis begins to push the gurney down the hall.
Hey. Can I leave now?
Don't see why not. Challis stops the gurney and extends his hand.
(continuing; professional courtesy) Thanks for helping him out.
Well, I always say...it may be me next time... (AD LIB)

(Jones' voice carries OVER.) -The..gurneyhas.stopped' just ;in: frontvof..an- open. do “Looking past Grimbridge's head, "SEE a PATIENT in’ bed, and high up on the wall, a television set. As we watch, the now-familiar happy music starts playing. The Silver Shamrock theme. Grimbridge hears it. His eyes pop open. He feebly raises his head! He moves his mouth, making a croaking sound.  © 20 21
Challis hears this and flies to Grimbridge, leaning in close.
Can you hear me? The commercial continues in BACKGROUND. Challis takes no notice.
({haltingly) They 're----going to----kill us! All of us!!! Grimbridge falls back, trembling.
Nurse! Nurse! As the nurse comes running, Jones backs fearfully away, down the hallway and out the door.
Grimbridge sleeps peacefully. The nurse finishes giving him an injection.
That ought to hold him 'til morning.
Great. Who's next?
Nobody.. Except. for him it's a quiet. night." .
I could use a nap.
Twenty-two's empty. They go into the hallway.  22 23 24 25
Challis and the nurse come out and head down the corridor away from CAMERA.
Pillows are in the cabinet. There's some milk and cookies in the fridge.

I think I should have married you, Agnes... He pats her on the behind. She jumps. NURSE . Watch it, buster. I play for keeps. They clown their way down the corridor, their voices receding. Challis goes into a room. The nurse ducks in at her station. After a moment, the tall thin man steps around a corner. He walks quietly across to Grimbridge'’s room. ‘
In the near-darkness, the thin man is no more than a shadow. He glides silently over to the bed.

Sleeping peacefully, lit dimly by a nearby nightlight. Suddenly a black-gloved hand clamps down across his mouth! His .eyesopen dazedly. His hands feebly claw at the glove;thé sleeve, but his strength is’no-match. for the thin man's.
The thin man brings his other hand down toward Grimbridge's face, his thumb and forefinger poised like talons!!
He stares up in terror, then he clamps his eyes shut as...
The thin man brings his hand down and...
The thumb and forefinger penetrate deep into Grimbridge's eye sockets! The hand grips hard, vice-tight.
His feet begin to kick and quiver.
Suddenly the gloved hand jerks outward with a Sickening CRUNCH. Grimbridge's face changes shape obscenely! Grimbridge stops struggling.
The thin man takes a towel from beside the bed and wipes his gloves on it.

(off-screen) ‘What are you. doing in heré?! WHIP PAN to the door. The nurse has come in, is already crossing to the bed. She sees Grimbridge; her hands fly to her mouth and she screams. The thin man walks calmly past her and out the door.
Challis springs up out of his nap; he runs into the hallway. The thin man slips out the exit door at the far end. Challis runs down the hallway and into Grimbridge's room.

He's dead! (pointing) A man--a man just--- Challis runs again. WE FOLLOW. Down the hallway, through a door, down a flight of steps, through another door and into the parking lot. Challis stops and looks around.
In the distance, the thin man reaches his car. He opens the door and gets inside.
He starts running for the car. WE FOLLOW, drawing close.
The thin man takes a container and begins to pour liquid on himself, the dashboard, the back seat!
Challis slows to a stop, mystified.
The thin man strikes a match.
For a split second, match-light illuminates the thin man's smooth, blank face. Wet with gasoline!  wo)
With a WHOOF, the car's interior roars into flame!
The wave of heat rocks Challis back on his feet. He stares at the burning car in astonishment and horror.
Within seconds, the entire car is an inferno! The gas tank explodes, sending a ball of flame into the air!
People run from surrounding building toward the flaming car, and the mystified doctor.
Same angle. POLICE hover about the charred car while TWO MEN IN WHITE COATS pick through the wreckage. A FIRE TRUCK sits nearby.

Challis stands at a window, bleary-eyed, still in shock. TWO ATTENDANTS lift Grimbridge's covered body onto a collapsible stretcher. The® SHERIFF;. the CORONER™and.another police OFFICER - talk quietly in the corner. The attendants wheel the stretcher to the door. They are met there by ELLIE GRIMBRIDGE, a pretty woman in her '20's. She is dressed in a suit, obviously prepared to. face the tragedy.
Is this ---- (CONTINUED)
The Sheriff crosses hastily over as Ellie starts to lift the sheet.
Ma'am, I wouldn't...just yet.
Let's get it over with. Gingerly, the Sheriff lifts the sheet. For just an instant, sheer horror plays across Ellie's face. She holds it in check. Challis watches from his place at the window.
(continuing) Yes...it's my father. She turns away, breathing deeply. The policeman hands her a cup of water. The coroner begins to pack his bag.
(continuing) Who did it?
Some crazy man. Killed himself in the parking lot right after... Drugs, probably. Miss Grimbridge--
Is that it? My father's dead because some drug freak was amusing himself?
The whole thing is under. investigation.
(bitterly) I'll bet!
Miss Grimbridge, you've had a hard night and you've come a long way. Nobody's sorrier than I am about what you've had to come for. Why (MORE) (CONTINUED)

(continued) don't you get some rest? When you feel better, I'll have some ques- tions for you. And maybe some more answers. The Sheriff pats Ellie's shoulder comfortingly. She straightens herself and walks out. Everyone waits for a pregnant moment. Then the Sheriff sighs hugely.
(continuing) . All right, boys. Let's clear out. The stretcher is wheeled out. One by one, the others follow.
Challis heads wearily toward the exit. A sound stops him. He looks around.
Down a side corridor, Ellie is pressed against a wall, half concealed, sobbing quietly.
He watches helplessly. : FADE OUT.

A television set is mounted high up over the bar. A Saturday morning cartoon is playing. There are two people in the bar: Challis and CHARLIE THE BARTENDER, a muscular fellow with a beard and a (CONTINUED)
beer gut. Challis is having bourbon for breakfast. He looks hung over. He winces at the cartoon.

Hey Charlie. How about another station? Charlie changes channels, pausing at a preview trailer for the movie "Halloween." An announcer intones promises of "a very special Horrorthon on Halloween night---brought to you by Silver Sham-
rock!" The familiar tones of the commercial follow..."THREE MORE DAYS TO HALLOWEEN, HALLOWEEN,
(continuing) Charlie, come on...
Whatsamatter? Don't you have any Halloween spirit?
No. Charlie finds a football game. He draws himself a beer and settles in to watch. The front door opens and Ellie walks in. She is casually dressed; she looks refreshed and well- rested.
{coming over) Hi.
Hello.
My name's Ellie Grimbridge.
I know. John Challis.
I know. (CONTINUED)
om
They sit awkwardly for a moment.
I---uh---I'm sorry about your father. I thought about calling or sending flowers or something, but...I figured you'd rather be left alone.
Thanks. You figured right. (after a moment) Can I ask you something?
Sure.
Do you do this every morning?
No! This is a special occasion!
What?

The weekend... . (glancing at his watch) It also probably has to do with the fact that I've got to pick up my kids in a little while and I'm not really looking forward to it. (holding up his drink) Get you one?
No thanks. Can I ask you something else? Challis nods, amused. Ellie is very attractive; she also knows how to ask questions without being obnoxious.
(continuing) Did my father say anything to you the night he died? Challis studies his drink for a moment. (CONTINUED)
Yeah. He said, 'tell Ellie I love her.'
(moved; rising to go) You're a bad liar...but thanks anyway.

Listen. I guess you have a right to know the truth. What he really said was, 'they're going to kill us all.' I hate to tell you this, but your old man was out of his mind. They found him wandering in the rain-- Challis stops. He has gone too far. Ellie fights back tears.
Could I show you something?
The store is dark. Ellie lets herself and Challis in. The front blinds are drawn; "closed" signs hang forlornly in the windows.

Papa really loved this place. But business was getting bad. I sup- pose you. shopped at the new mall like. everybody: élse.... Challis doesn't answer. He looks around the dusty store. It is a sort of hardware-variety store; a bit of everything. Along one wall is a rack of sports equipment. Next to that, a row of automobile tires. A shelf of toys. Tools, bicycles, clothing, arranged willy-nilly. (CONTINUED)

(continuing) He was thinking about closing down. His last letter was all about it. That was three weeks ago. (digging) He wasn't out of his mind then... She picks up an old-looking ledger by the cash register.

(continuing) The kids were keeping him going. They'd come in after school. He really loved them. Let 'em play with the stuff right in the aisles... like I used to do when I was little. (scanning the ledger) Candy, gum. A bicycle, a basketball, lots of toys...his best customers. (a beat) He kept pretty good records for a crazy man, Doctor--
Look, I'm sorry about the comment. Maybe I should go.
No. I did want to show you something. She picks up an appointment book.

(continuing; reading) ‘October 18, ° Merchant's council meeting. October 19; ‘football game. October. 20, pick up more masks.' That's the last entry. I think he was referring to these... She goes to a shelf where the Silver Shamrock masks are on display.
(wryly) Oh, those things. I know them well. (CONTINUED)
They're very popular. According to Papa's ledger, he couldn't stock them fast enough. I did a little detective work. The town where they make these is not too far away. Santa Mira.
So what?
If he went to the factory to pick up his order--
Why wouldn't he just have it sent?
Too close to Halloween? Besides, any merchant will tell you if you go to the factory direct, you'll cut your overhead! If Papa went there, then maybe they know some- oa thing I need to know. oS
(skeptically) Maybe.

My father wasn't crazy! And the Sheriff can talk all year about a drug-crazed lunatic running ber- serk and I still don't buy it. I'm surprised anybody does. (a pause) I'm not going:back to :L-A. until I find out what happened. ..maybe they can tell me something in Santa Mira. Challis eyes her for a long moment. Then:
Want some company?
a
Challis is at a pay phone. In the background, see Ellie's car, a rented Chevy. Double parked, Ellie at the wheel.

(into phone) Look Linda, I can't get out of it-- I'm really sorry--aah, just a bunch of doctors talking about boring stuff--Linda, take it easy!---I'll call you Monday---I can't remember the name of the hotel---I've got to go--~'Bye. He hangs up the phone, grabs a six-pack of beer perched on the phone booth, and hops into the car. It glides off into the California afternoon. PAN WITH IT and continue to: ...the show window of an appliance store. Rows and rows of TV sets. And on every one, the Silver Shamrock masks are dancing. The Shamrock theme is playing. The Sham- rock voice is pitching: "GLOWS IN THE DARK! ONLY
Ellie's car rolls past...
Ellie is driving, eating an apple and reading the map at the same time. Challis is sprawled across the seat, his head thrown back, sleeping soundly.
The Chevy swings off the highway onto a secondary road.
The car passes a quaint-looking farmhouse and disappears around a curve.
The car turns onto a lonely back road. distance is the ocean.
Ellie squints into the sunlight.
We're almost there...
(waking up) Mmmmf...hm?
There it is. Deep in the Ellie slows the car to a stop. They both look out.
The sleepy little town of Santa Mira sits nestled in rolling fields. Beyond it, a road leads off to the ocean, some miles away.
Challis stretches stiffly.
That crappy little place is where -all those masks and commercials come from? He settles .back.for another quick cat-nap. . Amused, Ellie drives on.

Looking out the windshield, SEE a big truck round the curve ahead, needing lots of room. It bears down on them. Ellie hits the horn and steers the car onto the shoulder. 55 56 57 58 59  60 61 61a 62 63
The truck lumbers past, narrowly missing Ellie's car, sending it deep onto the shoulder of the road.
Our two are thrown around a bit.

(shouting) Jerk! Challis spins around, watching the truck. HIS POV - THROUGH THE BACK WINDOW 61a The truck, featuring a Silver Shamrock logo on its ' side and back, rumbles around the curve and out of sight.
The car starts onto the road again. Another truck rounds the curve and roars out of town, again taking all the road. Ellie coughs in the dust.
Welcome to Santa Mira. Ellie rolls up her window and pulls onto the road again. EXT. “SANTA MIRA OUTSKIRTS - DAY . 63 The car rounds a curve and passes a large sign:

head_text.subj: WELCOME TO SANTA MIRA, HOME OF

text: In the distance, SEE for the first time, the red- brick factory. Smokestacks. A huge Silver Shamrock logo at the highest part of the building.
An old but pleasant-looking gas station sits next to a tiny Motel. On the hill behind this sits the Silver Shamrock factory.
RAFFERTY, the very Irish-looking attendant, stands beneath a sign bearing the inscription:
His eyes follow Ellie's car as it turns a distant corner.
Ellie's car pulls into the town square. It rolls along a row of stores. Most are closed down. No one is on the street.
Ellie and Challis watch the storefronts slide by.

A deserted storefront. A uniform shop (factory garb in the window); a neat and tidy little bank, "SHAMROCK SAVINGS"; a grocery, "SHAMROCK STORE"; and so on. Here and there, at windows and in doorways, ruddy Irish faces appear, take along look, then turn away.
I feel like a goldfish.
Company town.
Irish company town. 64 65 66 67 68 69

Ellie's car reaches the end of the row of buildings. It crosses a railroad track, turns in front of an old church and swings back around, one block over. PAN TO FOLLOW, finally revealing a strange object in foreground: Mounted up high on a rooftop, inconspicu- ous, is a small video camera. Its servo-unit whirs, following Ellie's car as it passes.
The car pulls up and pauses. BOOM DOWN CLOSE as our two look up at something.
The Silver Shamrock factory looms overhead, bathed in the golden light of the Autumn afternoon.
Looks a little spooky.
What do you expect? They make Halloween masks.
I'm not ready for this. We need a plan.
How about this: We drive down that road, ..get some more beer and .go’ to’ ‘the’ beach. “
I'm serious!

All right, here's one: We go back to that gas station and see if they know anything. We could pose as buyers. Maybe even rent a couple of rooms at that motel... (looking around furtively) Then we'd have someplace to talk without the whole town watching. (CONTINUED)

Good point. It's getting late, anyway. Ellie wheels the car down the street toward the gas station. After a moment, a garage door in the factory slides open. A long, silver limousine purrs into the street. Its windows are tinted; no hint of who might be inside. It heads off in the other direction.
Ellie's car pulls into the station. RAFFERTY comes over from the motel. Now he is all smiles, all charm, all Irish.
Good evenin' to ye! Fill ‘er up?
Please.
Aaah...and another grand day it's been in Santa Mira, where the sun smiles down and takes care of its own! He smiles his way to the pumps.
(under her breath) You've got to be kidding...
Welcome to Santa Mira. Dublin West.
(coming back) Just passing through?
No, I--uh, my husband and I-- (CONTINUED)
A surprised look from Challis.
(continuing) -7-own a toy store and we've come to pick up some more masks.
Ah, and beauties they are, too! Challis gets enthusiastically into the act. He leans forward and slides his arm onto Ellie's shoulders.
You can say that again! Selling like hotcakes, too!
(genuinely pleased) Gocod! Good!
Say, pardner. D'you know whether there's a vacancy next door? My wife and I need a place to stay. He smiles a "husband" kind of smile at Ellie, who tries not to crack up.

You've come to the right place. (fishing in his pocket) I own the motel, too! Well, rent it, really. Mr. Cochran owns it, of course. He owns everything around here. But he doesn't try to tell me how to run my business, and I don't try to tell him: how to run his. You see? It ‘all works out! Now! Here we are... He holds out a room-key, dangling from a large green Plastic tab.
The door opens, flooding orange light into a small but tidy room. Rafferty comes in, switching on lamps and fluffing up pillows on the lone double bed.
Here 'tis. It's cozy and it's quiet. (stepping into the bathroom) The shower's a good one... HEAR a blast of water, a clattering of pipes. Challis leans in close to Ellie.
{softly) Keep him happy for a minute. Challis leaves.
Challis hurries over to the motel office.
Rafferty comes out of the bathroom.
No bags?
Er...well, the trunk is stuck. (as Rafferty goes outside to help) My husband knows how. to do it, but.uhe went. to register...
Rafferty heads toward the trunk of the car.
Got the key? (CONTINUED)
Ellie comes over, stealing a glance toward the office. She pulls out a key ring with a dozen or so keys.
(feigning stupidity) I think it's this one...
Challis is leafing hurriedly through the guest register. He finds something of interest.
His finger runs down the list of names and finds a signature: HARRY S. GRIMBRIDGE, SIERRA MADRE, CA. ocT. 20.
The trunk pops open. Rafferty smiles.
My goodness! It certainly isn't stuck anymore, is it? There is one small overnight bag in the trunk. Rafferty grabs it.
Light packers, aren't you?
We've had a lot of practice. v Rafferty starts inside with the bag. He hears a car and turns.
Why, there's Mr. Cochran now! He waves and smiles enthusiastically.
The long silver limousine glides by slowly. 78 79 80 81 82  83 84 85 86 87
Seen from inside the limo: Ellie standing, Rafferty waving.
She watches the car go by. Rafferty heads inside with Ellie's suitcase.
Great man, Conal Cochran. A true genius...
Again from behind the dark glass, this time tight on Ellie's face. She watches intently.
The limousine tails away, past a large Winnebago just pulling into the motel. The vehicle is done up in loud colors. Recreational gear is stacked on top; a boy's bicycle is strapped to the grill.

Challis comes out of the office and along the walkway next to the rooms. The Winnebago blasts to a skidding stop just in front of Challis. The bicycle flops onto the ground at his feet with a CRASH. From somewhere inside the van comes a cry of distress: LI'L ‘BUDDY (off-screen) Daddeeeee! !! Challis sets the bike upright. A PORTLY MAN steps from the driver's seat. BUDDY KUPFER. Fortyish.
(into Winnebago) Aaah, it didn't hurt it! (MORE) (CONTINUED)

(continuing; coming around to Challis) Hey! Sorry about that. Glad it didn't hit you, and a great big "thank you" for picking it up! You all right? He thrusts out his hand. Buddy's not a bad sort of guy; just a little obnoxious. Challis shakes his hand and starts to pass.
No problem.
Buddy Kupfer. San Diego. That's my wife, Betty-- BETTY KUPFER, a perfect match for Buddy, wearing a bouffant hair-do, climbs out, followed by a miniature Buddy, LI'L BUDDY (12).
(continuing) --and right there's little Buddy! It's like the Mickey Mouse Club featuring overweight suburbanites.
Please to meetcha.
Is my bike busted? Li'l Buddy runsto his. bike, hops on-it ‘and rides off.
(screeching) Don't you dare go in the street! You hear me?
I've got to go... He backs away, is met by Rafferty. (CONTINUED)
Let's check you in now, sir.
I filled it out. There's forty dollars under the blotter. That cover it?
Yes! Thank you, sir! Have a pleasant stay. (turning to Buddy) Mr. Kupfer, I presume? Your rooms are waiting.
O.K., now this is a freebee, right? I mean, we could always stay in the R.V. if we need to-- Challis reaches his door and lingers there, listening.
I assure you, sir, Mr. Cochran o) has taken care of everything!
Well that's great! (to Betty, rummaging in the back of the Winnebago) Honey, it's a freebee!
(off-screen) What? Challis steps into his room and closes the door.
Challis leans against the door for a moment. Ellie is sitting neatly on the bed.
This place is a zoo.
I saw Cochran. His car, anyway. (CONTINUED)
You were right. Your old man stayed here on the 20th.
(standing) Bingo! Then we hit the factory first thing in the morning. (heading toward the bathroom) I'm going to take a shower. -O.K. with you?
Sure.
What I mean is, this bathroom is so tiny, I'd like to undress out here--
Oh! I'll get some air. {at the door) Listen, if it would make you more comfortable, I can sleep in the ear. It's softer than this floor anyway--
(softly; coming over) No, no, no... She touches his cheek. Then she plants a tiny kiss there.
~ (continuing) I ‘think we can do better than that... Challis thinks this, too. The ice is broken. He watches fondly as she crosses toward the bathroom unbuttoning her blouse. He goes out.
Challis enters the street at one end, walking toward the only storefront which is lit up. A neon sign advertizes "LIQUOR." Another one, "BEER."

The bathroom door is open. SEE Ellie in the shower through ripple glass. She finishes her shower and steps out, grabbing a towel. Freezing with this scant cover, she runs to the bed, grabs the bedspread and wraps it around herself, shivering.
The last hint of daylight leaves the sky. Mercury- vapor lights flicker’ on here and there. Challis comes out of the Liquor store carrying a bottle in a paper sack. He heads back the way he came.
Challis heads down the alley in back of the motel. SUDDENLY a FIGURE looms up out of the darkness beside him! Challis jumps back, startled. He drops the bottle, but it doesn't break.
Ho, mister! Didn't mean to scare you. I just saw that bottle of your'n and thought it looked pretty heavy. Challis picks up the bottle and says nothing.

(continuing) I. ain't got no diseases, and I wager I keep myself as clean as you do. How about a drink? Challis hands over the bottle. Starker leans into it, taking a good long pull. His face catches the light. It is an old face somehow, even though the man couldn't be more than forty. STARKER wears a brimmed hat and a ragged sports jacket. He is the local bum. (CONTINUED)
(continuing) Mmmm! God damn. Thank you. He hands the bottle back. Starts to move on.
Hey. You know anything about this big wheel named Cochran?

(snorting) Huh! Do I know anything? (dripping sarcasm) Why he made Santa Mira what it is today...a dried-up little pile of nothing! Used to be a pretty nice spot. Good people. Not any more. He bought 'em all. Every one of ‘em. Except me. I didn't have anything to sell. (a pause) I tried to get a job in his place. Let me tell you something. He brought in every damn one of them factory people from the outside. You think he'd hire me? Local boy? No way. Turned me down flat. So I make my money the hard way. You don't have a dollar you could spare, do you?
Challis searches his pocket, finds a dollar. Starker takes it, borrows the bottle again.

(continuing; another slug) Mmm!. God..damn... Thank you. ~ . . (handing the™bottlé back)” All I can tell you mister, is watch out. Seen the TV cameras yet? He's watching you, friend, I guarantee you that. (suddenly shouting)
Take it easy-- Starker staggers a step or two.

It's all right. Don't matter to me. He's probably listening. And if he is, I got one thing to say: This is the last Halloween for that lousy factory of his. They're pulling some wild shit in there, I've heard rumors... (wandering away) +-.this year I'm gon' get me about a case and a half of molotov cock- tails, mister...burn that sumbitch right down...last Halloween for them... Challis watches the man wander off down the alley. He moves off the other way.

Challis knocks, comes in. The light is low, romantic; Ellie is brushing her hair by the heater, still draped in the bedspread. A small portable radio is playing. Challis has found some ice outside. He sets every- thing down, makes himself a drink while he watches Ellie. She brushes her hair and watches him back.
Starker comes along, whistling. The trestle is thirty feet high. Its dark timbers cut zig-zag patterns. in the-night. sky.
Through the timbers, on Starker walking, whistling.
Starker stumbles, walks on.
Starker approaches CAMERA. Suddenly a harsh bright light bathes his face!
Huh?
Two black-gloved hands appear from behind and clamp Starker's arms to his sides. WHAP-WHAP!
A powerful flashlight is shoved up close to Starker's face. It is held by a black-gloved hand. Scrutinizing.
(suddenly sober) Hey fellas, I was just kidding! You know that, don't you? Kidding!
WHAM! He is forced suddenly to his knees .by the man in back. The man in front drops the flashlight into the weeds. These men, seen dimly, are wearing neat gray suits. Like the other assassin.
High angle looking down onto the bed. Ellie reclines languidly into frame,.letting. the bedspread, fall away. Challis follows, head and hand on her stomach. Kissing. The radio music is perfect...

head_text.subj: BACK TO STARKER, (FLASHLIGHT ON THE GROUND)

text: A closeup. The black gloves reach in and grab him firmly around each ear. The hands begin to tug. Starker's neck begins to stretch! Starker tries to scream!  we, 103 104 105
Ellie and Challis making love.
Backlit by the flashlight, the three figures are nothing more than abstract silhouettes as... The man in front gives a sudden heave and pulls Starker's head off.
Dark and quiet now. Challis and Ellie lying quietly in each other's arms. Radio playing softly. DOLLY IN. Then...the commercial comes on: "TWO MORE
It's too absurd. Laughing in disbelief, Challis snakes out his hand and shuts it off.
(lazily) It's late...
It's early, you mean. Get some sleep.
Hey.
Yeah?
I wouldn't have tried all this if you hadn't come along. (a pause) Thanks. They kiss and settle in for sleep.
Challis is sprawled across the bed, his arms dangling to the floor. Ellie wakes up frowning. She looks at her watch on the night table.
Damn! (holding her nose, talking announcerese) Calling Dr. Challis...calling Dr. Challis... (sees him stirring) It's already past noon.
The doctor isn't in right now...
(kissing his ear) No? He opens one eye and wraps his free arm around her. She smiles and rolls against him.
(CLOSEUP - SILVER SHAMROCK CLOCK)
3:30 on the clock. Ellie's car pulls up and our two get out, still looking sleepy.
Challis and Ellie walk up to a door marked "OFFICE." They:go inside.

Our two go down a short hallway and into a neutral office area. On the far wall is a large Silver Shamrock logo. Above it hangs a photo-portrait of a silver-haired, fatherly-looking gentleman (COCHRAN). A broad counter divides the receiving area from the office area, where a handful of OFFICE WORKERS go about their business. (CONTINUED)
A WOMAN is at the counter, heatedly talking to the HEAD SECRETARY. MARGE GUTTMAN is in her thirties; a little brassy, a wide, quick smile. She isn't smiling right now.
--well I just don't see any excuse for it! I called my order in day before yesterday! They said it would be ready!
Madam, please calm down--
I've got a business to run! If you think I'm going to stay here tonight just because somebody shuffled the wrong papers then you got another think coming, sister!
I assure you we're doing what we can--
Well try to do it just a little bit faster, all right? The secretary turns to Ellie and Challis. A rosy smile pops onto her face. Marge scowls and lights up a cigarette, puffing at it furiously.
May I.help you?
Yes. I--my father put in an order last week. Something's gone wrong. We never received it.
What firm do you represent?
Grimbridge's, Sierra Madre. (CONTINUED)
Just a moment. The secretary moves off toward a bank of file cabinets.

{to Ellie) Good luck. Their masks may be fabulous, but they're not too swift up here. (tapping her temple) I'm going to have to stay here tonight, I just know it. In that cruddy motel. It's the only place within fifty miles. The secretary returns with a yellow form.
There must be some mistake, dear. Our records show that Mr. Grim- bridge himself picked that order up on the 2lst. Here's his signature... Ellie scans the slip.
Well. Er--thank you. Do you-- remember that transaction?
As a matter of fact, I do! He was in a hurry, like-- (a glance at Marge) ~--like everyone else, this time of year.. elieve..Red- helped ’ him load his“car. " .
Red?
Yes. Would you like to speak with him? She hits a button on the counter. Immediately, too immediately, a RED-HEADED MAN comes through a door in back. (CONTINUED)
Og 109
(continuing) Red, these people lost an order. Did you load this one?
(scanning the sheet) Sure did. Last week. Man in an old green station wagon.
That's right! Did he say where he was going?
No.ma'am. He headed out to the north, though...I remember that.
. (disappointed) Thank you. She turns away.
Are you going to make another order, ma'am?
No. (to Challis) Let's go. There is a’ commotion in the hallway. Buddy, Betty and Li'l Buddy Kupfer burst in. They are dressed in their Sunday best. Buddy wears a smile as big as Texas.
Well! How you doin'? (to secretary) Buddy Kupfer and family... (proudly) --here to see Mr. Cochran.
(beaming) Yes, Mr. Kupfer! Welcome! I'11 tell Mr. Cochran you're here! (CONTINUED)
Tell him I'm here too, lady! Tell him I'd like some service! The secretary moves off.
Whenna we get to see 'em makin' the masks?
Real soon, little Buddy, real soon.
I'm hungry...
(to Challis) I've had enough. Let's get out of here.

Wait a minute... There is a stir at the back of the office. The typewriters fall silent. A door opens and in walks CONAL COCHRAN, an incredibly kind looking gentleman in a blue suit, white shirt and red tie. He is followed closely by TWO YOUNG IRISHMEN with rather blank faces, also in suits, these of gray. The effect is of legitimate, wealthy, corporate ower. But the gray suits are familiar. Last night. Starker's killers! Cochran moves easily through the office and up to the front counter. His voice has an Irish lilt to it. * : 7

So this is Buddy Kupfer, and his lovely family! (to the room) My friends, Mr. Kupfer has sold more Silver Shamrock masks this year by far, than anyone else on earth! The office workers break into applause. Cochran reaches out for Buddy's hand. Buddy is speechless, (CONTINUED)
in total awe of Cochran, button-burstingly proud. Betty beams; Li'l Buddy picks his nose.
(continuing) Silver Shamrock likes to do a little something special for its champion salesman each year, and that's why 4 you've been invited here. I hope your stay is a merry one, so I do!
(moved) ' Thank you! Thank you sir! , Again, the applause. Ellie and Challis exchange glances. It's a little bit strange. Cochran ; suddenly fastens his gaze on them, and on Marge.
1 And to my other friends, Ms. ) Guttman, correct?-— ' He goes to Marge, kisses her hand; she is instantly won over. He turns to Ellie and Challis.
(continuing) i --and Mr. and Mrs.--
Smith.

(amused) Smith; of course---my apologies for the confusion and the delays. i I. know you understand. i (an emphatic nod from Marge) It's the season, isn't it? But since you've lost time, and probably money through no fault of your own, I want you to know that you may take delivery of your full orders absolutely free of charge. It's on me. Marge gasps. The office-workers applaud again. (CONTINUED)
(reverently; to Betty) Is he incredible, or what?
And now, Mr. Kupfer, a guided tour for you and your family. And of course, our other friends-- (a sweeping gesture toward Marge, Ellie and Challis) --with your permission.
Oh, of course! By all means!

Shall we? One of the Graysuits holds open a door in the counter. One by one, the procession files through the office, past the beaming workers and through the door in back. Ellie and Challis fall in and follow.

Looking down a long, spacious room, SEE dozens of male and female MASKWORKERS standing at long tables, making the three Silver Shamrock masks: WITCH, SKULL and JACK-O-LANTERN. The place is strangely quiet; just the dull presence of a large room. Its light is constant; day or night. Our group enters through a door at one end. Little Buddy .is- first; he runs-~ ahead. NEW ANGLE lll Cochran takes the lead, talking easily, enjoying himself.
--the latex is heated and poured, then allowed to cool in the mold. Excess poured off, then it's just a lot of details, painting and packaging...
The process of maskmaking is illustrated by a series of shots: Heating, pouring, cooling, trimming, painting-- Cochran leads everyone through a small door at the other end of the factory.

Very low light. A series of display cases. A wall full of monster masks. A door marked "PRIVATE". Little Buddy darts through, ahead of the others. . He gives everything a quick look, .then moves on ahead, playing with his computer game. The others enter and spread out, as if at a museum. Here, a cluster of wonderful looking mechanical toys. There, a display case full of gag novelties. Buddy and Challis find themselves grouped together.
Oh, wow...this is it. This is really it. Hall of Fame time...
What's famous?
You really don't know? Conal Cochran? The all-time genius of the practical joke? He invented sticky toilet paper!
Oh.
You must know the Dead Dwarf gag. The Soft Chainsaw? All his!
(phony reverence) Gee, I didn't know... (CONTINUED)
“HALLOWEEN 3" 114

He manufactured the best boomer cushion in the business. It made a great sound-- (makes Bronx cheer) --really loud and convincing. The man has always paid attention to detail. Mechanical toys, masks... (going to a mask) Look at that paint job. Boy, I'm glad little Buddy's getting a chance to see these-- (braying)
(to Challis) : It's a real shame Mr. Cochran doesn't make this stuff anymore, but it wasn't paying off. Took a lot of guts for him to cut his losses and find something with some profit in it.
The masks?

You bet. The Big Halloween Three. Restrict the choices, lower the price, go for quality, simplify. Saturation advertising. Our a4 is on every major radio and TV station in the country! It's incredible!
Yeah... It is. .

You know what? By Halloween night, there'll be fifty million Silver Shamrock masks on fifty million heads out there. That's--- (groping) : that's unprecedented! Great to be on a winning team, isn't it? (CONTINUED)
“HALLOWEEN 3" REV. 4/4/82 47B. 114
(uneasily) Yeah. Theyfollow the others through another doorway.

Challis and Buddy come around a corner into a spacious receiving room. They stop and look. PAN AROUND. The beaming office workers have gathered here along with Cochran Marge and the others. A large cake and a punch bowl sit waiting. Decorations hang from the ceili Cochran holds a large ceremonial plaque out to Buddy.

Buddy Kupfer, it is my pleasure to present you with this year's Silver Shamrock Halloween Sales Award. Congratulations. Buddy steps forward, speechless. The office workers applaud. Betty beams. Li'l Buddy picks his nose. Ellie backs toward the Display Room.
Ellie comes in. The room is empty. She moves quickly over to a door marked "PRIVATE". She opens it. A.Graysuit is standing there. Looking at her.
Whoops. My mistake... She closes the door again. Another Darksuit separates himself from the shadows at the other end of the room.
(continuing) Have a nice day... She heads back toward the Main Room.
The office workers are making merry. Buddy is shaking Cochran's hand. Betty fishes in her purse and comes up with a camera. She hands it to a Graysuit, who obligingly snaps a picture.

Oh! And one more thing... {taking an envelope from his coat) A. small token of my appreciation. He hands the envelope to Buddy. There is a game-show sort of atmosphere prevalent as Buddy opens the envelope and gasps at what he sees. A check.
Five thousand dollars!

Oh my God... Betty throws her arms around Cochran's neck. More applause from the office-workers. Marge joins in. Challis and Ellie stand awkwardly to one side, staring at the spectacle, trading mystified glances.

It is a spacious area where a few MASKWORKERS stand, packing the masks in cardboard boxes. Our -group:enters .and passes through... Cochran.:is.the center of the Kupfer family's attention: Li'l Buddy rides Cochran piggy-back. Buddy and Betty walk arm in arm, smiling beatifically.
I want a mask! Can I have a mask?
Just what I had in mind for you, my young friend--
(pointing) I want that one! (CONTINUED)
(laughing) Oh, no no no no no! These masks haven't been. through final pro- cessing! This way... He moves off.
What's final processing? ' Everyone follows.

There is a maze of activity here: YARDMEN and DRIVERS scurry about, moving case after case of masks onto pallettes, onto trucks, onto converyors, onto fork lifts. Loaded trucks pull out of the yard, bound for the outside world.

Cochran and the others come out onto the platform. They are surrounded by activity. A truck is loaded. ‘ It pulls away. Boxes are stacked everywhere. Cochran nods at one of the Graysuits, who walks over to a stack of boxes outside a set of double doors marked NO ADMITTANCE. There is something about the door, the entranceway, that seems sinister, forbidding. The Graysuit picks up one of the boxes here and tears it open. Cochran, Li'l Buddy and Buddy come over. The Graysuit hands a Jack-o-lantern mask to Cochran. Buddy points at the double doors.
This final processing, Mr. Cochran-- what is it?
Oh, a bit o' this and a bit o' that...quality inspection, the seal of approval... (CONTINUED)
“HALLOWEEN 3" REV. 4/4/82 49a.
He shows Buddy the round Silver Shamrock seal on the mask. Then Cochran turns to Little Buddy.

In sharp foreground SEE the back of the mask as Cochran pulls it onto the boy's head. The seal is clearly visible now, in its place at the base of the neck-flap. Cochran surveys Li'l Buddy with delight. The old man claps his hands like a child. Li'l Buddy runs around 'scaring' people. Buddy points at the door again.
(to Cochran) So can we take'a look?
I'm sorry. Part of the inspec- tion process involved highly volatile chemicals. I'd hate to put anyone in danger.
Oh sure. I understand.
I do hope you and your family will join me tomorrow for breakfast. We'd like your opinion on some of our sales material.
My opinion? (flattered) Sure! Any time!
Challis is off to himself, looking the operation over. (CONTINUED)
cy 117 CONTINUED: 117 Ellie and Marge have paired off to one side, watching in the distance as Cochran makes some point to the others.

What a’ character. Did you know he's supposedly one of the richest men in the country? And he got there selling cheap gags and halloween masks...there's hope for me. I also heard that he lives here. Right in the factory.
How strange. - What-- Something catches Ellie's eye.
A forklift is driving into a dark garage. As the door is sliding shut, SEE just a glimpse of a green station wagon...
Ellie's eyes widen.
That was my father's--
Huh?
My God.
She starts running toward the garage.
Cochran sees her first. He tilts his eyebrows and the Graysuits run after her.
Challis, the others see her running. Confusion.
Ellie is nearly there when the Graysuits catch up with her. The car,
dammit! She stops, checking herself.
The car is-- He eyes her with new interest.
She stops fighting. They grab her firmly but politely. Behind her, workmen busy themselves locking the garage. One of the Graysuits points apologetically to a large sign above the garage door:
‘TLY NO Ellie composes herself and walks away from the garage, back to Challis.
The sun drops into the distant ocean, bathing the motel roof in brilliant orange FOR a moment, then darkness.
Challis is pacing. Ellie. is perched on the bed, visibly upset. I saw it.
I know
I saw it. Then I think it's time for the Marines. I'm scared.
I think we should leave. (CONTINUED)
All right. I've got no objections to that. Let me go call the Sheriff back home first. He can put us on the right track. This place falls under somebody's jurisdiction--
Hurry... Challis goes out the door. Ellie follows.
Challis hurries to the office. Ellie lingers near her car.
(off-screen) Mrs. Smith? Mrs. Smith! Ellie remembers her alias and spins around. Marge is standing in the doorway of another room. Ellie comes over.

(continuing) I just had to talk to somebody. May I show you something? She leads Ellie inside. INT. MARGE’S ROOM - NIGHT 128 Like the other motel room, only a different color. Marge. holds up a. disfigured witch-mask.

I sat this on the radiator. Dumb thing to do. It ruined the mask-- but then this little logo thing, the Silver Shamrock trademark, you know, it came off in my hand. And there's something very strange about it... She holds it under the desk-light, the only light source in the room.
The front of the seal. Then Marge's hands turn it over. On the back, planted dead center, is a micro- chip, visibly complex and colorful.
(continuing) Know anything about electronics?
No. Marge seats herself at the desk.

Well, all I know is, this thing is incredibly complex and sophisticated. What I don't know is, what does it ‘do? What is it for! And why is there one on each and every Halloween mask? (gesturing at a pile of masks on the bed) I don't get it... Ellie fights off a wave of dread and fear.
Perhaps my--husband might know more about this. I'll get him.

Great. And see if you can round up some batteries. These are too weak. She holds up her transister radio. She has pulled the batteries out of it and stacked them on the desk. ./ ELLIE ee! & Batteries?
Hell, I don't know what I'm doing. Thought maybe I could get it to lay, or light up, or whatever it's supposed to do--
Marge, be careful. (CONTINUED)
Oh, believe me, it's probably some stupid mixup. I told you before, at the lower levels of that organization, they're just out to lunch.
I'll be right back. Ellie hurries out. Marge turns to the trade-seals...
Challis is on the telephone, grimacing.
Well try again! Thank you. Ellie comes in.
Any luck?
Not so far--wait a minute-- (a beat) Hello, Sheriff? Dr. John Challis. Yes. We've got something here...
Marge puts on her reading glasses, studies the trade-seals, picks up the battery... Suddenly pulls. a‘hairpin.from*her-hair.. ‘She begins to ‘bend and twist it against ‘the batteries: =
(into phone) All right. We'll do that. Thanks. After we get to Leytonville. Right. Anything else? 129 130 131 132
. Marge bites her lip in fierce concentration. Hair- pins, battery terminals; the trade-seal slips from her fingers.
Damn! She tries again, blinking fiercely to clear her vision.
Marge's hands push the battery-charged hairpin against the trade-seal. There is a tiny sound and a tiny spark.
A small, brilliant light emanates from the trade- seal. Suddenly a blinding streak sears from the seal o directly into Marge's forehead!!!
Challis hangs up the phone.
Odd...
What? CHALLIS.”

He said there. was’ a mixup of some kind. The body of that man who burned up in the parking lot... ‘ They examined the wrong specimen. 4 Got him mixed up with the dash- board or something--all they had was a big pile of silicone.
Can this wait? What did he say about the police? e (CONTINUED)
He said to get the hell out and phone it in from Leytonville.
I think we should tell Marge. She's uncovered some kind of microchip on every mask. It's the strangest thing... They go out. '
Marge's door is slightly ajar. There is a strange sound coming from within, a faraway, barely-human wail... Our two come across the parking lot on the run, Ellie in the lead. She pauses at the door.
Marge? They go inside.
Sitting in the chair by the desk is a living horror that was formerly Marge. The desk lamp lies on the floor, overturned in the first convulsions.

Her eyeballs are the color of blood, the pupils gone. Her mouth is wide open, distended. forward and torn’ ragged by the blasting exhalation that has actually napped off eth -and.-rendered lips. into.stréaming oo ae laments: And: from this “opening. comes ‘the steady, : subhuman shriek...

Tiny rivulets of blood seep from her pores; she is still wearing her glasses. The frame has melted from intense heat. They droop on what is left of her nose. There is no intake of breath, just the dreadful exhaust-roar of her tattered voice. On and on and on... (CONTINUED)
For moments, Challis and Ellie can only stare in horror. Ellie's hands fly up to her own face, pulling at her skin.
Dear God, dear God...
Challis races out of Marge's room. CAMERA PANAGLIDES WITH HIM along the darkened motel rooms. He stops at Buddy's door. Knocks.
Buddy! No answer. Challis quickly moves on. Up to the office door. He bangs on it furiously. And glances over his shoulder.
Across the street, the factory. Lights on.
Rafferty opens the door. Looks out at.Challis.
Get an ambulance.
What...?
There's a woman down there--she's had some kind of...seizure or something...
Seizure? (CONTINUED)
She's been-- For God's sake, man--
Bad, is she?
Just get help! Challis starts back toward Marge's room.
There's no hospital.
What? There must be!
Only the clinic, that's all. Over in White Springs. About fifteen miles. That's all there is--
Call them!

Ellie stands near Marge. Staring at her. The fierce hissing wail has died away, as if Marge's condition has gone into a secondary phase. Her body is still racked with a steady shuddering but it is less violent. Faint, formless croaks come from her
throat. CLOSE-ON ELLIB go AN ee ee AB Staring.
Something moves at Marge's mouth. Two small, arachnid-like legs push their way out through Marge’s lips.  145 146 147 148 149 150 59.
Speechless. Horrified.
A_small, glistening spider crawls out of Marg mouth!
She turns and bolts for the door.
Ellie slams directly inte Challis outside the door.
John...Look at her mouth! Rafferty ambles up. They look in the door.
Marge sits motionless now. Looking dead. The spider is_gone from her ruined lips.
Rafferty peers in at.Marge. And reacts, but not quite as sharply as we might expect.
Whatever did it?.. Burns? It must have been -burns-- .
Have you ever seen anything like this before?
A couple. From the factory. They said it was chemical poisoning...
No, no...This thing came out of her mouth... (CONTINUED)
Rafferty looks around.
Not to worry. They're already coming. Challis and Ellie turn.
Several cars emerge from the factory. They move quickly toward the motel.
They'1l take care of her. Better than bouncin' her all over the countryside...
Are you going to call that ambulance?
I'm telling you, she'll be in better hands...
Then I'll do it.
(shrugs) Phone's in the office.
(to Ellie) Get your things. Quick. Challis and Ellie move off. Leaving Rafferty by Marge's door.
It's a company town. They provide everything...
Challis strides into the dark room. Up to the phone on the counter. A TV set is on in the darkness. A Silver Shamrock commercial is on. The dancing masked figures.

head_text.subj: TWO MORE DAYS, TWO MORE DAYS
KEEP YOUR EYES ON THE TV SCREEN...

text: Challis picks up the phone and dials. Behind him in the b.g. we see the cars from the factory pull into the motel parking lot.
(into phone) Operator, this is an emergency. A CLICK on the line.

(over telephone) I'm sorry, but we cannot complete your call as dialed. Please hang up and dial again. This is a recording. - Challis punches the cradle. Dials again. The lights from the factory cars swish through the office windows.

{over telephone) I'm sorry, but we cannot complete your call... Challis slams down the phone. CHALLIS' POV - ‘A JACK-O-LANTERN MASK 154 In the darkness of the room, a JACK-O-LANTERN mask lies on a chair. Challis' hand reaches in and grabs it.
Challis steps out of the office. Walks quickly down toward Marge's room. (CONTINUED)

Several cars have pulled in. GRAYSUITS and TECHNICIANS get out and converge around Marge's room. (We will see more of the Technicians later. They are dressed some- what like doctors.) Rafferty points inside Marge's room.
Ellie is throwing things into her suitcase. She's erying. Terrified.
Forget it. Just bring the car keys.

Challis moves from his room down to Marge's room. Several Technicians carry Marge out of her room on a stretcher. They move her quickly into a dark van. The van pulls away from the motel just as the long Cadillac silently pulls in. Cochran gets out. One of the Graysuits comes over.
(softly) We had a misfire. Cochran nods to him, then moves to Challis.
Evening, Mister Smith.....I'm: sure 2 “everything will be fines: “sorry: ~ 5 for any alarm this may have--
What is this? Challis holds up the Jack-O-Lantern mask. Points to the Silver Shamrock seal on the back.
(smiling) The seal of approval. Weren't you listening today? (CONTINUED)
i)
“HALLOWEEN 3"
It's full of micro-electronics. And somehow it kills, doesn't it?
Mister Smith...

It blew up in Marge's face... went off, did whatever it does. But you've seen what it can do before, haven't you? Challis tosses the mask at Cochran. It slaps against his leg and drops to the ground. Cochran smiles a benevolent, innocent smile.
Mister Smith, you've been under some strain, I-can see that. Now if you'll come with me to the factory, I'll show you the entire process. I think you'll see--
You're putting these things in the hands of children! Why?
I'll show you. Challis backs away.
No thanks. Not until I get a few people I know to come with mei we Challis starts back toward his room.

Challis and Ellie dart into the high-tech area. Before any of the technicians can react, Challis races to a console.
Challis' hand punches several buttons. Trying to find the right one.
Suddenly the large TV monitors in the corner flash to life! On each of them: the last TV commercial! Cochran spins around. Looks up toward the high-tech area.
Challis and Ellie race out of the high-tech area across a catwalk above Cochran and the guards.
Stop them! Suddenly the flashing strobe light begins on the monitors! CAMERA PUSHES IN. to Cochran's face! CocHRAN (continuing) Stop them!
Challis thrusts his hands into the box, grabbing handfuls of logos! He hurls them down! 292 293 294 295 296 297
The logos hit the flickering screen! A spark ZIPS, firing a micro-chip! Then another ZIP! And another!
A FACTORY GUARD is hit with a micro-chip! He instantly short-circuits! Silicone slime sprays out of his mouth! His body locks into a rigid position and falls to the floor!
Challis holds up the box and dumps it over the edge of the catwalk!
The tiny logos tumble downward, raining, turning!
The logos pass the screen. The sparks are ZIPPING everywhere!

The micro-chips find their targets! GUARDS shudder and go rigid all around as the sparks flash into them! They tumble to the floor! Cochran stands for a moment, looking up at Challis. He seems almost impressed by the turn of the tables. .Something .close to a smile.crosses his lips. And then he is covered with sparks! As if a swarm of fiery hornets. have covered him!

head_text.subj: ON CHALLIS AND ELLIE ON CATWALK 304

text: The flashing and sparking from below illuminate Challis and Ellie running away down the catwalk!  305 306 307 308 309

Cochran undergoes the most appalling change. He seems to be swelling to a monstrous size, towering above the fallen guards around him. His head is bulgin ushing outward into some strange shape! It continues to swell, melting, changing, into the shape of a grotesque pumpkin! Then Cochran collapses, a twitching heap on the floor! Dead!
The whole warehouse area is exploding. Sparks catching on the packing insulation. There are flames now.
Flames lick in the windows of the factory. Somewhere we hear a DULL EXPLOSION. Challis and Ellie race across the factory yard.
Ellie's car ROARS along the lonely road.
Challis drives like a madman... Ellie is
next to him in the ‘passenger. seat... Challis. turns on the’ radio.
+.-expecting overcast skies and a 50 percent chance of rain through Monday. It's presently 74 degrees at 8:48 p.m. Challis pushes down on the accelerator. (CONTINUED)
Gotta make it to that gas station! Another five or six miles... The Silver Shamrock commercial comes over the radio.

head_text.subj: TAKE YOUR MASK TO THE TV SCREEN

text: Challis CLICKS off the radio. He glances over at Ellie. She sits quietly in the seat.

Ellie, you all right...? Suddenly Ellie turns to Challis. A cold, blank expression on her face. There is just a beat. And_then she lunges for him! Her hand SNAPS across his face like a steel vice! Her other hand grabs the wheel of the car!
(a shriek)
The car swerves wildly along the road!

Challis and Ellie battle viciously. He tries to push her away but her strength is too much. She claws at his face. Leaving tracks of bloodied flesh. Challis SLAMS at her face with his fist! The blows register no impact! Her face is calm, emotionless! 98.
Ellie's hand yanks the wheel hard to the right!
The car heads right for a tree!
The front end buckled-in like a child's toy, the car THUMPS down to the ground from the impact! Challis tumbles out of the car, rolling across the ground. He shakily scrambles to his feet.
Ellie emerges from the other side. Stands up. And we see that one of her arms is missing! But still the calm, even expression on her face!

His face frozen with horror! He runs to the rear of the car! The trunk has sprung open. Challis reaches inside and grabs a tire iron. But suddenly, from around the side of the car, Ellie is_on him again, her single arm SNAPPING OUT and locking on his face! Challis raises the tire iron! And. SLAMS”it home! Right across Ellie's FACE! With a WHAP!
She staggers back stiffly. Silicone spewing from her mouth.
Moves forward. Raises the tire iron again. Swings.
WHANG! Ellie spins around, her head cocked at an impossible angle! Then she falls face forward to the ground!
He stares down at her.
Motionless. Eyes open. From the torn joint of her severed arm pours silicone. And we can see elec- tronics slowing, spinning to a stop.
Challis slowly moves back to the car.

He slides in. Puts the car in reverse. Tries to back it off the tree. But the car only GRINDS and rocks back and forth. Challis starts to slide back out. When Ellie's severed arm leaps up from the floor!
The fingers cla around his face!
Challis tumbles back out! The arm stuck fast to his head! (CONTINUED)
He rolls on the ground! Finally pulls the fingers off! And hurls the arm away from him! Then Challis scrambles to his feet.
The severed arm lies on the ground. The fingers still moving, clawing!
He turns away from the horror and races off into the night.
Challis, filthy and ragged, races up to the gas station. He halts wearily at the sight of a MAN emerging from the lighted booth. But as Jones comes nearer Challis rushes to him.
Gotta--use your phone! It's-- life and death--
Sure, man...don't I know you? Challis goes tottering into the gas station, followed by Jones.
It is minutes later. Challis is telephoning and keeping his eyes on the small, battered TV set. It is showing the last commercial. The sound is off.
{into phone; tormented) ...If it goes out it means the death of millions of people! Everyone watching! Do you under--then say it's a bomb! (MORE) (CONTINUED)
(continuing; into phone; nearly weeping) No, I can't prove...! You've got to believe me! Challis glances around for an instant.

Jones is in the doorway, watching him quizzically. And there are CHILDREN, a couple of them, standing behind Jones dressed in Halloween costumes. Each wears a Silver Shamrock mask! The TV screen flickers. The commercial vanishes abruptly! Followed by a station signal: "We Apologize For This Interruption..."
Relieved! He reaches to the TV set and CLICKS the channel changer.
The commercial! But _a second later it too is cut off! A card reads: "Stand By." Challis flips to another channel. The commercial is still there! Dancing JACK-O-LANTERN heads!
(into phone, frantically) The third channel...Get it off the air--get it off! Get it...!
In the doorway the CHILDREN watch. Now they move closer toward the TV set! All of them wearing their Silver Shamrock masks!
CAMERA MOVES IN on Challis as he watches in horror. Then the flashing, flickering starts from the TV, off-screen. The strobing light plays across his face. Glittering in his wild, terrified eyes!
(into phone, screaming) Turn it off! For God's sake, turn it off now! Stop it! (to attendant) Turn it off! Stop it! (to CAMERA) Stop it!
